name: Assumption Mapping
description: A structured technique to identify, visualize, and prioritize the assumptions behind a product idea—especially those that are risky and uncertain. Assumptions are plotted on a 2x2 matrix of Risk (impact if wrong) and Uncertainty (how confident we are it’s true). This helps teams focus validation efforts on the riskiest and least known aspects of their idea.
purpose: To avoid building products based on untested or invalid assumptions by proactively identifying and prioritizing what needs to be validated.
summary: Prioritize and de-risk product decisions by mapping assumptions based on uncertainty and impact.
originator: David J. Bland (Lean UX / Lean Startup practices)
seo_description: Use Assumption Mapping to prioritize what needs to be validated and avoid costly product mistakes.

examples.title: SmartCart's Auto-Filled Basket Risk Review
examples.description: To test their new 'Smart Weekly Basket' feature, the SmartCart team mapped key assumptions including 'users want baskets pre-filled based on history' and 'users trust SmartCart suggestions'.
examples.context: A product discovery workshop during a planning sprint for a major new automation feature.
examples.outcome: The team identified that the auto-filled basket assumption was both high risk and high uncertainty, leading to early validation via user interviews and a concierge MVP.
